elements.content: Four divalent copper coordination polymers containing both 1,2-phenylenediacetate (1,2-phda) and dipyridyl-type coligands have been prepared and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. {[Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)]·H2O} n (1, dpa = 4,4′-dipyridylamine) possesses a simple (4,4) rhomboid polymeric grid structure but can be considered a (4,6)-connected binodal supramolecular lattice with (4462)(446108) fsc topology. Use of a longer dipyridyl ligand afforded [Cu2(1,2-phda)2(dpp)] n (2, dpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane), which manifests a rare self-penetrated rob lattice (48668 topology) built from the linkage of copper dicarboxylate layers through crossed dpp tethers. [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(4-bpmp)0.5] n (3, 4-bpmp = bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) forms a 5-connected Archimedean cem layer with 334453 topology. The topology of 3 can be alternately described as a 3,4-connected binodal layer with a V2O5-type network. Incorporation of nitrate counterions led to formation of {[Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)] (NO3)·4.5H2O} n (4), a layered coordination polymer with hydrogen-bonded water molecule/nitrate ion chain motifs situated in the interlamellar regions. Strong antiferromagnetic coupling (J = −278(3) cm−1 with g = 2.28(1)) was observed within the {Cu2(OCO)4} “paddlewheels” in 2, while weak ferromagnetic superexchange (J = 3.5(9) cm−1 with g = 2.12(4)) along the {Cu(OCO)} n was evident in 3.

elements.content: Copper coordination polymers containing 1,2-phenylenediacetate (1,2-phda) and dipyridyl ligands are reported. {[Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)]·H2O} n (1, dpa = 4,4′-dipyridylamine) possesses a rhomboid grid structure. [Cu2(1,2-phda)2(dpp)] n (2, dpp = 1,3-di(4-pyridyl)propane) manifests a rare self-penetrated lattice. [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(4-bpmp)0.5] n (3, 4-bpmp = bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine) forms a 5-connected Archimedean layer. {[Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)](NO3)·5H2O} n (4) exhibits double layers. Strong antiferromagnetic coupling is observed in 2, while weak ferromagnetic superexchange occurs in 3.

elements.content: The synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers remain under intensive investigation, with efforts geared toward the design of materials tailored to diverse applications such as hydrogen storage, molecular separations, ion exchange, catalysis, and nonlinear optics. Dicarboxylate ligands are among the most commonly employed linkers in coordination polymers, providing structural rigidity to the resulting phases, and preventing inclusion of small anionic species in most cases. The disposition of the donor groups around the periphery of the dicarboxylate ligands, the coordination preferences at the specific metal ions, and different carboxylate binding and bridging modes act synergistically to provide access to vast numbers of structural topologies. Additionally, spin communication between paramagnetic metal ions can be fostered by carboxylate bridges. The resulting interactions hinge on the population, orientation, and overlap of the respective magnetic orbitals.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers remain under intensive investigation, with efforts geared toward the design of materials tailored to diverse applications such as hydrogen storage, molecular separations, ion exchange, catalysis, and nonlinear optics. Dicarboxylate ligands are among the most commonly employed linkers in coordination polymers, providing structural rigidity to the resulting phases, and preventing inclusion of small anionic species in most cases. The disposition of the donor groups around the periphery of the dicarboxylate ligands, the coordination preferences at the specific metal ions, and different carboxylate binding and bridging modes act synergistically to provide access to vast numbers of structural topologies. Additionally, spin communication between paramagnetic metal ions can be fostered by carboxylate bridges. The resulting interactions hinge on the population, orientation, and overlap of the respective magnetic orbitals.

elements.content: Neutral dipyridyl-type coligands, such as 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), can pillar dicarboxylate coordination polymer motifs into higher dimensions, appreciably altering the overall structural topology. Previous results have indicated that dipyridyl ligands with flexible central tethers, such as 1,2-di-4-pyridylethane (dpe) and 1,3-di-4-pyridylpropane (dpp), can be successfully utilized to prepare coordination polymers with topologies that vary considerably from their bpy-based analogues. Recently, our group has been probing the synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers containing the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridyl ligands 4,4′-dipyridylamine (dpa) and bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp). The additional length of these ligands, as compared to bpy, in tandem with their additional hydrogen-bonding structure-directing facility, has allowed construction of dual-ligand divalent metal coordination polymers with intriguing topologies. For example,{[Ni(dpa)2(succinate)0.5]Cl} n displays a self-penetrated 5-connected three-dimensional (3-D) network with a regular 610 topology, while {[Cd(phthalate)(dpa)(H2O)]·3H2O} n manifests a unique multiple helix-based 4-connected self-penetrated network with 7482 topology. {[Cd(succinate)(4-bpmp)(CH3OH)]·2H2O} n possesses a layered two-dimensional (2-D) 658 topology, with the standard (4,4) grid structure precluded by the length mismatch between the short dicarboxylate and long-spanning 4-bpmp ligands.

Previous results have indicated that dipyridyl ligands with flexible central tethers, such as 1,2-di-4-pyridylethane (dpe) and 1,3-di-4-pyridylpropane (dpp), can be successfully utilized to prepare coordination polymers with topologies that vary considerably from their bpy-based analogues. Recently, our group has been probing the synthesis and characterization of coordination polymers containing the hydrogen-bonding capable dipyridyl ligands 4,4'-dipyridylamine (dpa) and bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine (4-bpmp). The additional length of these ligands, as compared to bpy, in tandem with their additional hydrogen-bonding structure-directing facility, has allowed construction of dual-ligand divalent metal coordination polymers with intriguing topologies. For example,{[Ni(dpa)2(succinate)0.5]Cl} n  displays a self-penetrated 5-connected three-dimensional (3-D) network with a regular 610 topology, while {[Cd(phthalate)(dpa)(H2O)]⋅3H2O} n  manifests a unique multiple helix-based 4-connected self-penetrated network with 7482 topology. {[Cd(succinate)(4-bpmp)(CH3OH)]⋅2H2O} n  possesses a layered two-dimensional (2-D) 658 topology, with the standard (4,4) grid structure precluded by the length mismatch between the short dicarboxylate and long-spanning 4-bpmp ligands.

elements.content: In the present work we have sought to investigate the topological effects of dipyridyl ligand length on divalent copper coordination polymers incorporating 1,2-phenylenediacetate (1,2-phda), that has ortho-disposed carboxylate substituents similar to phthalate but with more flexible pendant arms. Four coordination polymers were obtained: {[Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)]·H2O} n (1), [Cu2(1,2-phda)2(dpp)] n (2, dpp), [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(4-bpmp)0.5] n (3), and {[Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)](NO3)·4.5H2O} n (4). The specific structural requirements imposed by the length and hydrogen-bonding ability of dipyridyl coligands, and conformational adjustments within the 1,2-phda acetate arms, act in tandem to alter the carboxylate binding modes, in turn providing different coordination polymer dimensionalities and topologies. Magnetic studies were undertaken to probe spin communication in 2 and 3.

elements.content: Copper salts and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid were purchased from Aldrich. 1,3-(Di-4-pyridylpropane) was purchased from TCI America. 4,4′-Dipyridylamine (dpa) and bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine were prepared using published procedures. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data (2 to 300 K) was collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1 T. After each temperature change, the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5 min before magnetization measurements to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal’s constants. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 Thermogravimetric Analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

Copper salts and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid were purchased from Aldrich. 1,3-(Di-4-pyridylpropane) was purchased from TCI America. 4,4'-Dipyridylamine (dpa) and bis(4-pyridylmethyl)piperazine were prepared using published procedures. Water was deionized above 3 MΩ-cm in-house. IR spectra were recorded on powdered samples using a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum One instrument. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility data (2 to 300 K) was collected on a Quantum Design MPMS SQUID magnetometer at an applied field of 0.1 T. After each temperature change, the sample was kept at the new temperature for 5 min before magnetization measurements to ensure thermal equilibrium. The susceptibility data were corrected for diamagnetism using Pascal's constants. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a TA Instruments TGA 2050 Thermogravimetric Analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C/min up to 900 °C.

elements.content: CuCl2·2H2O (52 mg, 0.31 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid (75 mg, 0.39 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 24 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Purple blocks of 1 (94 mg, 0.21 mmol, 68% yield based on Cu) were isolated after washing with distilled water, hot ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Use of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as the copper salt resulted in a powdery purple solid. Anal. Calc. for C20H19N3O5Cu 1: C, 53.98; H, 4.30; N, 9.44% Found: C, 54.61; H, 4.00; N, 9.47%. IR (cm−1): 3184 w, b, 3048 w, b, 1590 s, 1558 w, 1523 s, 1488 m, 1446 m, 1352 s, 1307 m, 1212 s, 1168 w, 1139 w, 1086 w, 1073 w, 1058 w, 1021 m, 945 w, b, 910 w, 825 m, 813 m, 776 w, 741 m, 727 w, 700 m, 683 w, 668 m, 663 m.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on a purple block of 1, a green block of 2, a green plate of 3, and a small blue plate of 4 using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite−monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the nitrogen atoms of the dpa ligands in 1, the aqua ligands in 3 and 4, the 4-bpmp piperazine nitrogen atom in 4, and most of the unligated water molecules were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. The nitrate counteranion in 4 was disordered over two positions (3:1 ratio) that share one nitrogen and one oxygen site. Mediocre R 1 and wR 2 values for 4 are ascribed to the rather small crystal size. Relevant crystallographic data for 1−4 are listed in Table . Topological analyses were carried out using TOPOS software.

X-ray Crystallography

Single crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on a purple block of 1, a green block of 2, a green plate of 3, and a small blue plate of 4 using a Bruker-AXS ApexII CCD instrument at 173 K. Reflection data were acquired using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated via SAINT. Lorentz and polarization effect and empirical absorption corrections were applied with SADABS. The structures were solved using direct methods and refined on F 2 using SHELXTL. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms bound to carbon atoms were placed in calculated positions and refined isotropically with a riding model. The hydrogen atoms bound to the nitrogen atoms of the dpa ligands in 1, the aqua ligands in 3 and 4, the 4-bpmp piperazine nitrogen atom in 4, and most of the unligated water molecules were found via Fourier difference maps, then restrained at fixed positions and refined isotropically. The nitrate counteranion in 4 was disordered over two positions (3:1 ratio) that share one nitrogen and one oxygen site. Mediocre R 1 and wR 2 values for 4 are ascribed to the rather small crystal size. Relevant crystallographic data for 1-4 are listed in Table . Topological analyses were carried out using TOPOS software.

Compounds 1−3 were prepared cleanly as crystalline products by hydrothermal reaction of copper salt and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid with the requisite dipyridyl ligand. Compound 4 was obtained as a minor product from the preparation of 3. Numerous attempts to prepare a clean sample of 4 by using sodium nitrate or nitric acid additives in the procedure, and varying temperature, were unfortunately unsuccessful.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Spectral Characterization

Compounds 1-3 were prepared cleanly as crystalline products by hydrothermal reaction of copper salt and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid with the requisite dipyridyl ligand. Compound 4 was obtained as a minor product from the preparation of 3. Numerous attempts to prepare a clean sample of 4 by using sodium nitrate or nitric acid additives in the procedure, and varying temperature, were unfortunately unsuccessful.

elements.content: The infrared spectra of 1−3 were consistent with their structural characteristics as determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Medium intensity bands in the range of ∼1600 cm−1 to ∼1200 cm−1 can be ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of nitrogen-base ligands. Puckering modes of the pyridyl rings are evident in the region between 820 cm−1 and 600 cm−1. Asymmetric and symmetric C−O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated 1,2-phda ligands correspond to the strong, broadened features at ∼1520 cm−1 and ∼1350 cm−1 (for 1), ∼1600 cm−1 and ∼1380 cm−1 (for 2), or ∼1530 cm−1 and ∼1390 cm−1 (for 3). The differences in Δν between the carboxylate bands reflect differences in the binding mode of the 1,2-phda ligands across the series 1−3. Broad yet weak bands in the region of ∼3400 cm−1 to ∼3200 cm−1 represent N−H stretching modes within the dpa ligands and O−H bonds within ligated and/or unbound water molecules. The broadness of these higher energy spectral features is caused by the hydrogen bonding present in all cases (see below).

Medium intensity bands in the range of ~1600 cm-1 to ~1200 cm-1 can be ascribed to stretching modes of the pyridyl rings of nitrogen-base ligands. Puckering modes of the pyridyl rings are evident in the region between 820 cm-1 and 600 cm-1. Asymmetric and symmetric C-O stretching modes of the fully deprotonated 1,2-phda ligands correspond to the strong, broadened features at ~1520 cm-1 and ~1350 cm-1 (for 1), ~1600 cm-1 and ~1380 cm-1 (for 2), or ~1530 cm-1 and ~1390 cm-1 (for 3). The differences in Δν between the carboxylate bands reflect differences in the binding mode of the 1,2-phda ligands across the series 1-3. Broad yet weak bands in the region of ~3400 cm-1 to ~3200 cm-1 represent N-H stretching modes within the dpa ligands and O-H bonds within ligated and/or unbound water molecules. The broadness of these higher energy spectral features is caused by the hydrogen bonding present in all cases (see below).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains two divalent copper atoms on crystallographic inversion centers, one dpa molecule with an inter-ring torsion angle of 20.0°, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one water molecule of crystallization (Figure ). Each copper atom displays {CuN2O2} square planar coordination, with trans nitrogen donor atoms from dpa ligands and trans oxygen donor atoms from 1,2-phda carboxylate groups. Bond lengths and angles are consistent with the coordination geometry and are listed in Table .
elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of {[Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)]⋅H2O} n  (1)

The asymmetric unit of compound 1 contains two divalent copper atoms on crystallographic inversion centers, one dpa molecule with an inter-ring torsion angle of 20.0°, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one water molecule of crystallization (Figure ). Each copper atom displays {CuN2O2} square planar coordination, with trans nitrogen donor atoms from dpa ligands and trans oxygen donor atoms from 1,2-phda carboxylate groups. Bond lengths and angles are consistent with the coordination geometry and are listed in Table .

The crystallographically distinct copper atoms (Cu1 and Cu2) are joined by 1,2-phda ligands in a bis(monodentate) bridging mode to form [Cu(1,2-phda)] n chain motifs that are oriented parallel to the (1 0 1) crystal direction. Within the chain pattern, the Cu···Cu through-ligand distance is 8.676 Å. The pendant acetate groups of the 1,2-phda ligands are twisted by 84.5° and 97.1° relative to the plane of the aromatic ring. Parallel [Cu(1,2-phda)] n chains are linked into a 2-D [Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)] n (4,4) grid coordination polymer layer (Figure ) by dpa ligands, with through-ligand Cu···Cu contact distance of 11.703 Å. This layer motif exhibits two different grid aperture sizes, depending on the orientation of the aromatic rings of the 1,2-phda ligands. The larger aperture window measures 5.48 × 12.21 Å as determined by acetate C···C and dpa amine H···H distances; the smaller window measures 4.834 × 12.21 Å as determined by phenyl C···C and dpa amine N···N contact distances. Both grid spaces are rhomboid in shape, with Cu···Cu···Cu angles of 74.95 and 105.05°. The [Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)] n layers are situated parallel to the [1 1̅ 1̅] crystal planes.

Within the chain pattern, the Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu through-ligand distance is 8.676 Å. The pendant acetate groups of the 1,2-phda ligands are twisted by 84.5° and 97.1° relative to the plane of the aromatic ring. The larger aperture window measures 5.48 × 12.21 Å as determined by acetate C⋅⋅⋅C and dpa amine H⋅⋅⋅H distances; the smaller window measures 4.834 × 12.21 Å as determined by phenyl C⋅⋅⋅C and dpa amine N⋅⋅⋅N contact distances. Both grid spaces are rhomboid in shape, with Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu angles of 74.95 and 105.05°. The [Cu(1,2-phda)(dpa)] n  layers are situated parallel to the [1 1̅ 1̅] crystal planes.

elements.content: Adjacent layers stack in an AAA pattern along the b crystal direction (), connected to each other by supramolecular hydrogen bonding between the dpa amine groups and unligated oxygen atoms (O2) belonging to the 1,2-phda carboxylate groups bound to Cu1 (Table ). The water molecules of crystallization lie in the interlamellar region, anchored by long-range “4 + 2” Cu···O interactions (2.953 Å); they occupy a scant 3.5% of the unit cell volume as determined by PLATON. If the hydrogen bonding interactions are treated as direct linkers, the supramolecular topology of 1 can be rendered as a (4,6)-connected binodal lattice with (4462)(446108) topology (fsc network) (Figure a) in which the Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are 6- and 4-connected nodes, respectively. Alternatively, if the central nitrogen atom of the dpa ligands are considered to be 3-connected nodes, a supramolecular (3,4,6)-connected trinodal lattice with a point symbol of (4.62)2(6482)(426883102) can be invoked (Figure b).

The water molecules of crystallization lie in the interlamellar region, anchored by long-range "4 + 2" Cu⋅⋅⋅O interactions (2.953 Å); they occupy a scant 3.5% of the unit cell volume as determined by PLATON. If the hydrogen bonding interactions are treated as direct linkers, the supramolecular topology of 1 can be rendered as a (4,6)-connected binodal lattice with (4462)(446108) topology (fsc network) (Figure a) in which the Cu1 and Cu2 atoms are 6- and 4-connected nodes, respectively. Alternatively, if the central nitrogen atom of the dpa ligands are considered to be 3-connected nodes, a supramolecular (3,4,6)-connected trinodal lattice with a point symbol of (4.62)2(6482)(426883102) can be invoked (Figure b).

The interlayer connections are shown in purple. (b) Network perspective of the alternate (3,4,6)-connected trinodal supramolecular lattice in 1. The light blue spheres represent the central amine nitrogen atom of the dpa ligands.

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 consists of a divalent copper atom, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one-half of a dpp ligand whose central methylene unit is located on the crystallographic 2-fold rotation axis (Figure ). The coordination environment at copper is a nearly ideal {CuO4N} square pyramid (τ = 0.004), with bond lengths and angles consistent with a Jahn−Teller distorted d 9 metal ion (Table ). The basal plane is taken up by carboxylate oxygen atom donors from four different 1,2-phda ligands, while a dpp pyridyl nitrogen donor atom occupies the apical site. Each copper ion is bridged to another by four 1,2-phda carboxylate groups to construct {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel units with a Cu···Cu distance of 2.626 Å. The paddlewheels are connected through the 1,2-phda tethers, thereby forming [Cu(1,2-phda)] n coordination polymer layers that lie parallel to the ac crystal planes (Figure ). The pendant arms of the 1,2-phda ligands are twisted by 50.6 and 91.0° relative to the plane of the aromatic rings, which mark the perimeters of the papilionaceous apertures within the coordination polymer layer motif.

Structural Description of {[Cu2(1,2-phda)2(dpp)] n  (2)

The asymmetric unit of compound 2 consists of a divalent copper atom, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one-half of a dpp ligand whose central methylene unit is located on the crystallographic 2-fold rotation axis (Figure ). The coordination environment at copper is a nearly ideal {CuO4N} square pyramid (τ = 0.004), with bond lengths and angles consistent with a Jahn-Teller distorted d 9 metal ion (Table ). The basal plane is taken up by carboxylate oxygen atom donors from four different 1,2-phda ligands, while a dpp pyridyl nitrogen donor atom occupies the apical site. Each copper ion is bridged to another by four 1,2-phda carboxylate groups to construct {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel units with a Cu⋅⋅⋅Cu distance of 2.626 Å. The paddlewheels are connected through the 1,2-phda tethers, thereby forming [Cu(1,2-phda)] n  coordination polymer layers that lie parallel to the ac crystal planes (Figure ). The pendant arms of the 1,2-phda ligands are twisted by 50.6 and 91.0° relative to the plane of the aromatic rings, which mark the perimeters of the papilionaceous apertures within the coordination polymer layer motif.

Adjacent [Cu(1,2-phda)] n layers are connected by tethering dpp ligands along the b crystal direction to establish a noninterpenetrated [Cu(1,2-phda)(dpp)0.5] n 3-D coordination polymer lattice (Figure ). The central methylene tether of the dpp is arranged in an anti-anti conformation (four C-atom torsion angles = 174.0°). Each {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel unit connects to six others: four within the [Cu(1,2-phda)] n layers and two through a pair of dpp ligands. Thus, the 3-D coordination polymer lattice in 2 can be considered a 6-connected lattice. The through-ligand Cu···Cu distance across the dpp ligands measures 13.184 Å, which is longer than the closest Cu···Cu through-space distance between layer motifs (12.973 Å). As a result the 6-connected network cannot adopt the common 41263 primitive cubic (pcu, α-Po) topology. Instead, this network possesses a very rare self-penetrated 48668 rob topology (Figure ) (Long Vertex Symbol: 4.4.4.4.4.4.4.4.64.64.68.68.68.68.∞; coordination sequence: 6, 22, 52, 94, 148, 214, 292, 382, 484, 598). A close-up of the self-penetration of the dpp linkers through six-membered circuits in the lattice is depicted in . The self-penetrated rob network of 2 is identical to that within the 6-connected coordination polymers [Cu2(glutarate)2(bpy)] n and {[Cu2(2-methylglutarate)2(bpy)]·1.1H2O} n . However, these previously reported phases were both originally not identified as self-penetrated lattices; in addition the latter species had been misidentified as possessing a primitive cubic 41263 topology.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of compound 3 contains one divalent copper atom, one 1,2-phda dianion, and one-half of a 4-bpmp ligand situated across the crystallographic inversion center (Figure ). The copper atom possesses a distorted square pyramidal (τ = 0.223) {CuO4N} coordination environment. The basal plane is filled by two 1,2-phda carboxylate oxygen atoms in a trans orientation, along with an aqua ligand and a 4-bpmp pyridyl nitrogen donor atom, also situated trans with respect to each other; the apical position is occupied by a third 1,2-phda carboxylate oxygen atom. Bond lengths and angles about copper are consistent with a Jahn−Teller distorted d 9 electronic configuration (Table ).

Each 1,2-phda ligand connects three copper atoms in an exotridentate bis(bridging)/monodentate binding mode, thereby constructing 1-D [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)] n ribbon motifs that are aligned parallel to the b crystal direction. Within these ribbons, 1-D {Cu(OCO)} n chains are evident, formed by carboxylate groups bridging equatorial coordination sites on adjacent copper atoms in an anti-syn fashion. The pendant arms of the 1,2-phda ligands are twisted by 67.9 and 87.5° relative to the plane of the aromatic rings, resulting in a carboxylate-bridged Cu···Cu distance within the 1-D {Cu(OCO)} n chains of 4.771 Å. The Cu···Cu intrachain distance across the 1,2-phda carboxylate termini is 8.156 Å, which defines the b lattice parameter.

elements.content: Individual [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)] n ribbons are pillared by tethering 4-bpmp ligands to build 2-D [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(4-bpmp)] n coordination polymer layers (Figure ), oriented parallel to the (2 0 1̅) crystal direction. The Cu···Cu distance across the 4-bpmp ligands measures 16.312 Å. Within the layer, each Cu atom connects to five others: two through OCO carboxylate bridges, two through the full extent of 1,2-phda ligands, and one through the 4-bpmp tether. With each Cu atom serving as a 5-connected node, the framework of 3 can be considered to be a cem Archimedean layered net with 334453 topology, built from stacked triangles and rectangles (Figure a). An alternative perspective of this layered coordination polymer topology can be obtained by treating the exotridentate 1,2-phda ligands as 3-connected nodes, and the Cu atoms as 4-connected nodes joining to three 1,2-phda ligands and one other Cu atom through 4-bpmp tethers. The resulting 3,4-connected binodal layer topology (Figure b) mimics a V2O5-type structure, with a Schafli symbol of (426)(42638). Neighboring [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(4-bpmp)] n coordination polymer layers aggregate by cooperative hydrogen-bonding between the aqua ligands and unligated carboxylate oxygen atoms (Table , ).

elements.content: The asymmetric unit (Figure ) of compound 4 consists of a divalent copper atom, a fully deprotonated 1,2-phda ligand, an aqua ligand, a 4-bpmp molecule protonated at one of its piperazinyl nitrogen atoms along with a nitrate anion (two of whose oxygen atoms are disordered) and a total of four and one-half water molecules of crystallization. The coordination environment at copper is best described as a very distorted {CuO3N2} square pyramid, with a τ value of 0.33. Pyridyl nitrogen donor atoms from two H4-bpmp ligands and carboxylate oxygen atoms from two 1,2-phda ligands occupy respective trans positions within the basal plane; the apical site is taken up by an aqua ligand. The lengthening of the apical Cu−O bond is consistent with the Jahn−Teller active d 9 electronic configuration. Relevant bond lengths and angles for 4 are listed in Table .

Extension of the structure of 4 through the bis(monodentate) 1,2-phda ligands generates 1-D [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)] n neutral chains, with a Cu···Cu distance of 9.224 Å, approximately 1.1 Å longer than in its nitrate-free congener 3. The lengthening of the Cu···Cu bridging distance is attributed to the more open torsion angles of the acetate arms of the 1,2-phda ligands (81.5 and 95.8° relative to the plane of the aromatic ring). Parallel [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)] n neutral chains are pillared by H4-bpmp ligands to form [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(H4-bpmp+)] n n+ (4,4) cationic coordination polymer grids. The Cu···Cu distances through the H4-bpmp+ tethers measure 16.039 Å, which delineates the b crystal parameter. All Cu···Cu···Cu angles around the grid perimeters measure an exact 90°.

elements.content: Pairs of [Cu(1,2-phda)(H2O)(H4-bpmp)] n n+ coordination polymer grids form supramolecular dual-layer slabs (Figure ) by N−H···O hydrogen bonding between the protonated piperazinyl nitrogen atoms of the H4-bpmp+ ligands and unligated 1,2-phda carboxylate oxygen atoms. Adjacent sheets stack in an AAA pattern (), held together by hydrogen-bonding involving the bound water molecules and the water molecules of crystallization. The water molecules of crystallization themselves form D7 discrete chains with isolated water molecules hydrogen-bonded at the third and fifth positions, in a pattern resembling that of 3,5-dimethylheptane. These water molecule aggregations are bridged by pairs of nitrate anions to construct 1-D supramolecular chain motifs (). Hydrogen-bonding information is given in Table above. According to PLATON, the nitrate counterions and unligated water molecules occupy 23.6% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication in 2 and 3. At 300 K the χm T product for 2 was 0.311 cm3-K mol Cu−1, less than expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 spin. The χm T value decreased rapidly to 0.069 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 100 K, reaching 0.0061 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 2 K, signifying strong antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic data above 25 K were fit to the Bleaney−Bowers expression for a pair of coupled S = 1/2 spins, including the mole fraction of paramagnetic impurities (ρ) (eq ). The best fit values (Figure ) were g = 2.28(1), J = −278(3) cm−1, with ρ = 0.031(1) and R = 1.36 × 10−5 = {Σ[(χm T)obs − (χm T)calc]2/Σ[(χm T)obs]2}), indicating extremely strong antiferromagnetic coupling via direct mechanisms between face-on d x 2−y 2 orbitals across the equatorial-equatorial bridged{Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. The observed strong antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 is similar to that seen in [Cu2(μ-acetate)4(H2O)2] and other complexes containing {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. It is likely that any magnetic coupling through the 1,2-phda or dpp tethers is negligible. χ m T = 2 N g 2 β 2 k [ 3 + exp ( − J / k T ) ( 1 − ρ ) + N g 2 β 2 2 k ( ρ )

Magnetic Properties of 2 and 3 

Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication in 2 and 3. At 300 K the χm T product for 2 was 0.311 cm3-K mol Cu-1, less than expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 spin. The χm T value decreased rapidly to 0.069 cm3-K mol Cu-1 at 100 K, reaching 0.0061 cm3-K mol Cu-1 at 2 K, signifying strong antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic data above 25 K were fit to the Bleaney-Bowers expression for a pair of coupled S = 1/2 spins, including the mole fraction of paramagnetic impurities (ρ) (eq ). The best fit values (Figure ) were g = 2.28(1), J = -278(3) cm-1, with ρ = 0.031(1) and R = 1.36 × 10-5 = {Σ[(χm T)obs - (χm T)calc]2/Σ[(χm T)obs]2}), indicating extremely strong antiferromagnetic coupling via direct mechanisms between face-on d  x 2-y 2  orbitals across the equatorial-equatorial bridged{Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. The observed strong antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 is similar to that seen in [Cu2(μ-acetate)4(H2O)2] and other complexes containing {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. It is likely that any magnetic coupling through the 1,2-phda or dpp tethers is negligible. 1    χ   m   T =    2 N   g   2     β   2     k [ 3  +  exp ( - J / k T )   ( 1 -  ρ )  +    N   g   2     β   2     2 k   ( ρ )

elements.content: For 3, the χm T product at 300 K was 0.430 cm3-K mol Cu−1, slightly higher than that expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 spin. This value increases extremely slowly upon cooling, attaining 0.478 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 50 K, then increasing more rapidly, reaching 0.636 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 10 K and 1.41 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 2 K. The increasing values of χm T indicate ferromagnetic coupling along the {Cu(OCO)} n chains in 3. Magnetic data for 3 obeyed the Curie−Weiss law (), with C = 0.427 cm3-K mol Cu−1 and Θ = +3.8 K, indicating ferromagnetic coupling between adjacent copper ions. The variable temperature magnetic data were fit to Baker’s expression for a isotropic S = 1/2 chain (eq ), with best fit values (Figure ) of g = 2.12(4), J = 3.5(9) cm−1, with R = 1.1 × 10−2. elements.content: Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on compounds 1−3 to investigate their dehydration and degradation behavior. Between 75 and 225 °C, compound 1 underwent a 4.1% mass loss, corresponding well with ejection of the water molecules of crystallization (4.0% calcd). Combustion of the organic components occurred between ∼225 °C and ∼510 °C. The remnant at 900 °C of 21.1% of the original mass corresponds to a possible deposition of CuO (17.9% calcd) along with some uncombusted organics. No mass loss for compound 2 was observed until ∼220 °C, whereupon pyrolysis of the organic components commenced. The mass of 50.4% by ∼275 °C matches roughly with that predicted for elimination of the 1,2-phda ligands (54.1% calcd). The final remnant of 21.7% at 900 °C matches well with that expected for a deposition of CuO (22.3% calcd). Compound 3 shows an insignificant mass loss between room temperature and ∼180 °C, whereupon elimination of the bound water molecules and organic ligands began. The mass remnant of 17.4% at 900 °C matches roughly with that expected for a deposition of CuO (19.4% calcd).
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on compounds 1-3 to investigate their dehydration and degradation behavior. Between 75 and 225 °C, compound 1 underwent a 4.1% mass loss, corresponding well with ejection of the water molecules of crystallization (4.0% calcd). Combustion of the organic components occurred between ~225 °C and ~510 °C. The remnant at 900 °C of 21.1% of the original mass corresponds to a possible deposition of CuO (17.9% calcd) along with some uncombusted organics. No mass loss for compound 2 was observed until ~220 °C, whereupon pyrolysis of the organic components commenced. The mass of 50.4% by ~275 °C matches roughly with that predicted for elimination of the 1,2-phda ligands (54.1% calcd). The final remnant of 21.7% at 900 °C matches well with that expected for a deposition of CuO (22.3% calcd). Compound 3 shows an insignificant mass loss between room temperature and ~180 °C, whereupon elimination of the bound water molecules and organic ligands began. The mass remnant of 17.4% at 900 °C matches roughly with that expected for a deposition of CuO (19.4% calcd).

elements.content: Divalent copper dual-ligand coordination polymers containing aromatic dicarboxylates with ortho-disposed flexible pendant arms show significant structural diversity depending on the length of the nitrogen coligand. When the dicarboxylate and dipyridyl ligands had comparable girth, as in compound 1, a common (4,4) rhomboid grid topology was obtained. Nevertheless, if hydrogen-bonding is taken into account, an uncommon (4,6)-connected binodal lattice can be invoked for 1. Inclusion of a flexible trimethylene tether within the dipyridyl component permitted formation of a rare 6-connected self-penetrated rob network in 2. Generation of the usual 6-connected primitive cubic topology is precluded by the higher packing efficiency instituted by the self-penetration. Use of the even longer-spanning 4-bpmp ligand resulted in the construction of a 5-connected Archimedean net within the structure of 3. Although compound 4 could not be prepared cleanly, it indicates that the central piperazinyl nitrogen atoms of the 4-bpmp ligands can be protonated, resulting in the necessity of anion inclusion for charge balance. It is quite possible that deliberate adjustment of anions could provide an ability to direct structure formation in divalent metal dicarboxylate/4-bpmp dual-ligand coordination polymers. Structural diversity in this system is also enhanced by the ability of the 1,2-phda ligands to adopt different binding modes (bis(monodentate) in 1, bis(chelating) in 2, bis(bridging)/monodentate in 3) in response to the steric requirements of the nitrogen coligands, promoted by conformational variances within the flexible acetate pendant arms. The different binding modes of the 1,2-phda ligands also provide access to different magnetically active substructural motifs, with strongly antiferromagnetically coupled {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheels in 2 and ferromagnetically coupled {Cu(OCO)} n 1-D chains in 3.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Divalent copper dual-ligand coordination polymers containing aromatic dicarboxylates with ortho-disposed flexible pendant arms show significant structural diversity depending on the length of the nitrogen coligand. When the dicarboxylate and dipyridyl ligands had comparable girth, as in compound 1, a common (4,4) rhomboid grid topology was obtained. Nevertheless, if hydrogen-bonding is taken into account, an uncommon (4,6)-connected binodal lattice can be invoked for 1. Inclusion of a flexible trimethylene tether within the dipyridyl component permitted formation of a rare 6-connected self-penetrated rob network in 2. Generation of the usual 6-connected primitive cubic topology is precluded by the higher packing efficiency instituted by the self-penetration. Use of the even longer-spanning 4-bpmp ligand resulted in the construction of a 5-connected Archimedean net within the structure of 3. Although compound 4 could not be prepared cleanly, it indicates that the central piperazinyl nitrogen atoms of the 4-bpmp ligands can be protonated, resulting in the necessity of anion inclusion for charge balance. It is quite possible that deliberate adjustment of anions could provide an ability to direct structure formation in divalent metal dicarboxylate/4-bpmp dual-ligand coordination polymers. Structural diversity in this system is also enhanced by the ability of the 1,2-phda ligands to adopt different binding modes (bis(monodentate) in 1, bis(chelating) in 2, bis(bridging)/monodentate in 3) in response to the steric requirements of the nitrogen coligands, promoted by conformational variances within the flexible acetate pendant arms. The different binding modes of the 1,2-phda ligands also provide access to different magnetically active substructural motifs, with strongly antiferromagnetically coupled {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheels in 2 and ferromagnetically coupled {Cu(OCO)} n  1-D chains in 3.

CuCl2·2H2O (52 mg, 0.31 mmol), dpa (127 mg, 0.74 mmol), and 1,2-phenylenediacetic acid (75 mg, 0.39 mmol) were placed into 10 mL of distilled H2O in a 23 mL Teflon-lined Parr acid digestion bomb. The bomb was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 24 h, whereupon it was cooled slowly to 25 °C. Purple blocks of 1 (94 mg, 0.21 mmol, 68% yield based on Cu) were isolated after washing with distilled water, hot ethanol, and acetone and drying in air. Use of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O as the copper salt resulted in a powdery purple solid. Anal. Calc. for C20H19N3O5Cu 1: C, 53.98; H, 4.30; N, 9.44% Found: C, 54.61; H, 4.00; N, 9.47%. Variable temperature magnetic susceptibility studies were carried out to investigate spin communication in 2 and 3. At 300 K the χm T product for 2 was 0.311 cm3-K mol Cu−1, less than expected for an uncoupled S = 1/2 spin. The χm T value decreased rapidly to 0.069 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 100 K, reaching 0.0061 cm3-K mol Cu−1 at 2 K, signifying strong antiferromagnetic coupling. The magnetic data above 25 K were fit to the Bleaney−Bowers expression for a pair of coupled S = 1/2 spins, including the mole fraction of paramagnetic impurities (ρ) (eq ). The best fit values (Figure ) were g = 2.28(1), J = −278(3) cm−1, with ρ = 0.031(1) and R = 1.36 × 10−5 = {Σ[(χm T)obs − (χm T)calc]2/Σ[(χm T)obs]2}), indicating extremely strong antiferromagnetic coupling via direct mechanisms between face-on d x 2−y 2 orbitals across the equatorial-equatorial bridged{Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. The observed strong antiferromagnetic coupling in 2 is similar to that seen in [Cu2(μ-acetate)4(H2O)2] and other complexes containing {Cu2(OCO)4} paddlewheel dimers. It is likely that any magnetic coupling through the 1,2-phda or dpp tethers is negligible. χ m T = 2 N g 2 β 2 k [ 3 + exp ( − J / k T ) ( 1 − ρ ) + N g 2 β 2 2 k ( ρ )

Thermogravimetric Analysis

Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out on compounds 1−3 to investigate their dehydration and degradation behavior. Between 75 and 225 °C, compound 1 underwent a 4.1% mass loss, corresponding well with ejection of the water molecules of crystallization (4.0% calcd). Combustion of the organic components occurred between ∼225 °C and ∼510 °C. The remnant at 900 °C of 21.1% of the original mass corresponds to a possible deposition of CuO (17.9% calcd) along with some uncombusted organics. No mass loss for compound 2 was observed until ∼220 °C, whereupon pyrolysis of the organic components commenced. The mass of 50.4% by ∼275 °C matches roughly with that predicted for elimination of the 1,2-phda ligands (54.1% calcd). The final remnant of 21.7% at 900 °C matches well with that expected for a deposition of CuO (22.3% calcd). Compound 3 shows an insignificant mass loss between room temperature and ∼180 °C, whereupon elimination of the bound water molecules and organic ligands began. The mass remnant of 17.4% at 900 °C matches roughly with that expected for a deposition of CuO (19.4% calcd).
